page.title: Nominal Phrases - AdjP Modifiers
page.introduction:
Adjective phrases (AdjP) come next, discussed earlier in
Adjectives and AdjP. This means we will be able to parse nominal phrases such as these in English:

EnglishExample.exItem: just those very few old, dirty books.
all the boy's many black dogs.
only the first one hundred very eager young boys.

page.introduction: As the English examples show, more than one adjective phrase is allowed before the noun. This will be handled in the syntactic parser by a recursive rule.

radioGroup.prompt: Where do adjective phrases occur with respect to the noun?
Can all the adjective phrases appear on either side of the noun?
radioGroup.radio: No, there are separate sets for each side

form.instruction:
Note that the head of these participle phrases is categorically a verb, so these are derived adjectivals. They will remain verbs in our grammar rules, but need to be distinguished as participles so that only the participle forms of verbs may be used as adjectives. The appropriate features will be added in section
Basic, Single-Clause Sentences - Inflection Features
form.introduction:
Languages which change the case of the head noun when a possessor is present normally also change the case of intervening adjectives to match. Some languages of this type also change the case of the head noun when only an adjectival modifier is present, even when there is no possessor.
Further, some languages of the latter type have an overt affix which marks the genitive case (or the normal case of possessors) on the head noun to indicate that there must be either an adjective or a possessor in that nominal phrase. In this situation, the adjective and/or possessor will also be in genitive case (or the normal case of possessors), though the case marking will not be overt on the highest modifier in the nominal phrase.

radioGroup.prompt: Does the presence of a adjective change the case marking on the head noun to match the normal case of a possessor, with or without a possessor also present?
radioGroup.radio: No, the case of the head noun only changes when a possessor is present, though in that situation an intervening adjective may/must also carry that case
Yes, the case of the head noun changes to match the normal case of a possessor even if just an adjectival modifier is present

radioGroup.prompt: Is there an overt case affix that marks the genitive or ergative absolutive case (the normal case of possessors) on the head noun which, when present, indicates that there must be either an adjective or a possessor in that nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: No, genitive or ergative absolutive case marking is not handled in this distinctive way

Yes, a prefix: when the overt genitive or ergative absolutive prefix is present on the head noun, it indicates that an adjectival modifier and/or a possessor must be present in the phrase. (If the adjective is marked with this genitive or ergative absolutive prefix then another adjective and/or a possessor must also be present.)

Yes, a suffix: when the overt genitive or ergative absolutive suffix is present on the head noun, it indicates that an adjectival modifier and/or a possessor must be present in the phrase. (If the adjective is marked with this genitive or ergative absolutive suffix then another adjective and/or a possessor must also be present.)

radioGroup.prompt: Do adjectives carry any marking to agree with the noun they modify?

form.instruction:
In the lexicon, key the feature genitive_prefix or
ergative_prefix
absolutive_prefix on the phrase-delimiting affix which marks genitive or ergative absolutive case.

In the lexicon, key the feature genitive_suffix or
ergative_suffix
absolutive_suffix on the phrase-delimiting affix which marks genitive or ergative absolutive case.

In the lexicon, mark those adjectives which can only occur before the noun with the feature DP-initial and those which can only occur after the noun with the feature DP-final. Do not enter either feature on any adjective which can occur on either side.

You said your language does not mark any agreement in
Overview Plus Agreement and Case, so it is unclear what agreement marking adjectives may have. Return to
Overview Plus Agreement and Case and change your answer appropriately if you do have agreement marking. If not, change your answer here to "no".

To handle the number agreement, in the lexicon:
Mark the adjectives (or appropriate affixes) that only go with singular nouns with the feature singular.
Mark the adjectives (or appropriate affixes) that only go with plural nouns with the feature plural.
If your language makes a further distinction for dual marking, add the feature dual to the appropriate adjectives, if any.

To handle animacy agreement:
Mark the adjectives (or the appropriate affixes) that can only go with animate nouns with the feature animate.
Mark the adjectives (or the appropriate affixes) that can only go with inanimate nouns with the feature -animate.
Do not add any animacy agreement feature to those which can go with either animate or inanimate nouns.

Add the gender features masculine, feminine, neuter to any adjectives (or the appropriate affixes) that can only go with that type of noun. Do not add any gender agreement feature to those which can go with either masculine or feminine nouns.

To handle class marking and agreement, in the lexicon:
Mark the adjectives that can only go with a particular class with the feature class_##, where ## is replaced by a number between 1 and 99.
It may be the case that the same affixes that mark the class number on nouns are also used on adjectives. If this is the case in your language, you should have already added the class feature to the affixes, so all the words will automatically come from the morphological parser with the class number marked.
